Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Interface-induced misfolding and aggregation of intrinsically disordered proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Chi, Eva
CBET - 1150855

Intellectual Merit

NON-TECHNICAL:

Despite the implication of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) in a number of human diseases, the aggregation mechanism of IDP by which the disease develops remains poorly understood. The objective of this proposal is to gain a fundamental understanding of how interfaces in the cellular environment can affect the misfolding and aggregation of IDPs. The PI will investigate the aggregation of two IDPs implicated in Alzheimer¡¦s disease (AD), the amyloid-£] (A£]) peptide and the tau protein. Successful completion of the proposed research will advance current understanding of not only the interfacial effects on the structural dynamics of an important class of proteins, but also of the mechanism and thermodynamic driving forces underlying the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases.

TECHNICAL:

The PI proposes a novel aggregation mechanism in which an IDP first forms an aggregation-competent intermediate that is partially folded and proceeds through a structurally contracted transition state. This step is followed by the assembly of intermediates to form larger aggregates. The PI hypothesizes that interfaces can induce IDP structural compaction, lowering the activation free energy of aggregation and template nucleation. The PI further hypothesizes that these interfacial effects are significantly amplified under conditions that mimic the cell milieu, namely, macromolecular crowding and the presence of osmolytes. The PI hypothesizes that attenuating the binding of A£]'n peptide and tau protein to biological interfaces can inhibit their aggregation and toxicity. To test these hypotheses, the PI proposes the following three objectives that build on her research group¡¦s unique strengths in thermodynamics of protein aggregation, biophysical analysis of proteins in solution and at interfaces, and biochemistry. The PI proposes to accomplish the following three research objectives: 1) to evaluate the likelihood and affinity of four tau proteins to partition to two interfaces, the air/water interface and the lipid membrane interface, and characterize changes in tau structure and aggregation kinetics accompanying the binding of the proteins to the interfaces; 2) to study the effect of molecular crowding and osmolytes on A£]'nand tau¡¦s surface activity, membrane interaction, and aggregation to test if interfacial forces stemming from excluded volume and preferential exclusion can modulate interface-templated IDP aggregation; 3) to investigate whether attenuation of the binding of A£]'nand tau to lipid membranes can ameliorate their aggregation and toxicity.

Broader Impacts

The proposed research, deeply rooted in molecular thermodynamics and interface science, represents a novel approach to studying the aggregation of IDPs. The analysis of intermolecular interactions and interfacial forces that govern the assembly of IDPs represents a fundamental scientific challenge that is of great importance in biology and medicine. Understanding of the mechanism and thermodynamic driving forces of IDP aggregation gained from the proposed study is of paramount importance in advancing the current knowledge of the molecular mechanism underlying the pathogenesis of Alzheimer¡¦s disease. Determining the aggregation mechanism of IDPs could potentially lead to therapeutic strategies for treating such neurodegenerative diseases.

In terms of education, the PI is committed to furthering her contribution to the establishment of New Mexico¡¦s first Biomedical Engineering undergraduate and graduate degree programs through new course development and student recruitment. The PI is also strongly dedicated to expanding and augmenting the existing outreach efforts at the University of New Mexico to rural Native American elementary schools and introducing a new hands-on demonstration module focusing on the molecular aspects of protein structure and denaturation to Albuquerque High School students. The PI will continue mentoring efforts to Native American students from the Southwest Indian Polytechnic Institute helping them make a successful transition to the University of New Mexico. The cumulative and long-term impact of the proposed educational and outreach efforts will be increased enrollment and retention of students in bioengineering, particularly underrepresented minorities and women, which will spark economic vitality and meet future work force demands in New Mexico and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) comprise a novel class of proteins that is disproportionally prevalent in diseases. The objective of this project is to elucidate the mechanism and thermodynamic driving forces of the misfolding and aggregation of two IDPs implicated in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease, the amyloid-beta peptide (Ab) and the tau protein. Importantly, little is known about the molecular basis of early aggregation events and the nature of the structural fluctuations that trigger the aggregation of the otherwise stable and unstructured Ab and tau. Using a combined high-resolution experimental and large-scale computational simulation approach, we investigated the role interfaces, including the air/water and lipid membrane interfaces, played in modulating the structure and aggregation propensity of the Ab40 peptide and 4 variants of the tau protein.

Intellectual Merit.  Owing to their soft nature, the Ab and tau proteins were found to be highly surface active, readily partition to the air/water interface lowing its surface tension, and favorably interacted with lipid monolayers composed of anionic DMPG, but not zwitterionic DPPC, lipids at the air/water interface. Strikingly, both Ab and tau interacted with the model lipid membrane and gave rise to in-plane diffraction peaks, as detected by synchrotron grazing-incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXD), with a characteristic d-spacing of 4.74 Å and an averaged size of the ordered domains of a few hundred angstroms. This d-spacing exactly matches the beta-sheet spacing in Ab and tau fibrils, indicating that these membrane-induced protein assemblies, are composed of Ab and tau misfolded in a beta-sheet conformation. Concomitant with Ab and tau misfolding and assembly, lipid in-plane packing in the membrane became disrupted. Our findings support a general IDP aggregation mechanism where the protein’s inherent surface activity drives protein-lipid membrane interactions, inducing the misfolding and self-assembly of the protein into beta-sheet enriched oligomers that could subsequently seed fibril growth and deposition into diseased tissues. Moreover, protein surface activity and membrane interactions are significantly enhanced in the presence of neutral co-solutes due to preferential hydration and volume exclusion, indicating that behaviors of IDPs at interfaces are amplified in the cell milieu. Small membrane-active molecules such as the naturally occurring flavonoid curcumin that reduces protein-membrane interactions also reduces Ab aggregation, membrane disruption, and toxicity.

Broader Impacts. Our findings give insights into the structure, dynamics, and function of an important class of proteins, IDPs. Interface-mediated misfolding and assembly behaviors of Ab and tau also give insights into the mechanism and driving forces of the protein aggregation events during the early stages of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. Insights into these aggregation events can lead to elucidating the link between pre-clinical pathophysiological processes and emergence of clinical symptoms and thus creating a crucial “pre-clinical” window of opportunity to intervene with disease-modifying therapy. This project has contributed towards the education and training of a large number of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs. In total, 2 postdocs, 5 graduate students, and 24 undergraduates worked on various topics for this research project, 65% of which are female and 32% of which are underrepresented minorities. In addition to student training, the development of a graduate level course related to this search project have contributed towards the development of the only Biomedical Engineering program in the state of New Mexico.
